Description: Mould-made oil-lamp of human face. Holes in forehead and chin. No base and almost egg-shaped. Incised palm frond mark monogram on base. Relatively shallow, with small hole in the centre, and a hole at the narrower end. Shaped base with no handle. Yellowish tan fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

3rd to 4th century AD parallel from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA III.3). This type was found in early/mid 2nd century AD contexts at Mons Claudianus, with a good parallel from an Antonine context (Knowles 2006, 382-3, no. 90). Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton. Knowles, K. 2006. The pottery lamps. In V.A.Maxfield and D.P.S. Peacock Survey and excavation at Mons Claudianus 1987-1993. Vol.3 Ceramic vessels and related objects. IFAO Cairo. 309–426.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.49) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5878 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
